questions.question: When rounded to the nearest hundred, a number becomes 74,500. When rounded to the nearest thousand, the same number becomes 75,000. What could the number be?
questions.explanation: For rounding to nearest hundred to give 74,500, the number must be between 74,450 and 74,549. For rounding to nearest thousand to give 75,000, the number must be between 74,500 and 75,499. The overlap is 74,500 to 74,549. Only 74,532 falls in this range.

questions.question: Alex has 5 times as many toy cars as Ben. Ben has 3 times as many toy cars as Chris. Together they have 95 toy cars. How many toy cars does Alex have?
questions.explanation: Draw 1 box for Chris. Ben has 3 boxes (3 times Chris). Alex has 5 times Ben, so 5 × 3 = 15 boxes. Total boxes = 1 + 3 + 15 = 19 boxes. 19 boxes = 95 cars, so 1 box = 95 ÷ 19 = 5 cars. Alex has 15 boxes = 15 × 5 = 75 cars.

questions.question: Round 86,374 to the nearest ten, then round your answer to the nearest hundred.
questions.explanation: First, round 86,374 to nearest ten. Look at ones digit (4). Since 4 is less than 5, round down to 86,370. Next, round 86,370 to nearest hundred. Look at tens digit (7). Since 7 is 5 or more, round up to 86,400.

questions.question: I am thinking of a number. I multiply it by 4, then subtract 60. Next, I divide by 5. The result is 28. What is my number?
questions.explanation: Work backwards step by step. Start with 28. Since we divided by 5 last, multiply 28 by 5 to get 140. Before that, we subtracted 60, so add 60 to 140 to get 200. Before that, we multiplied by 4, so divide 200 by 4 to get 50. The number is 50.

questions.question: Complete the pattern: 98,765, 97,654, 96,543, _____
questions.explanation: Look at each digit position. Ten-thousands: 9,9,9 → stays 9. Thousands: 8,7,6 → decreases by 1 each time, next is 5. Hundreds: 7,6,5 → decreases by 1, next is 4. Tens: 6,5,4 → decreases by 1, next is 3. Ones: 5,4,3 → decreases by 1, next is 2. The next number is 95,432.

questions.question: A fruit seller had some apples. He sold half of them in the morning. In the afternoon, he sold 120 apples. He had 180 apples left. How many apples did he have at first?
questions.explanation: Work backwards. After afternoon sales, he had 180 apples left. Before afternoon sales, he had 180 + 120 = 300 apples. These 300 apples were half of what he had at first (because he sold half in the morning). So at first he had 300 × 2 = 600 apples.

questions.question: A number has 7 in the ten thousands place, 3 in the thousands place, and 9 in the tens place. All other digits are zero. What is the number?
questions.explanation: Ten thousands place is the 5th digit from right: 7 _ _ _ _. Thousands place is 4th digit: 7 3 _ _ _. Tens place is 2nd digit from right: 7 3 _ 9 _. Ones place is zero: 7 3 _ 9 0. Hundreds place is zero: 7 3 0 9 0. The number is 73,090.

questions.question: Tom had some money. He spent $80 on a game. Then he spent half of the remaining money on snacks. He had $120 left. How much money did Tom have at first?
questions.explanation: Work backwards. After buying snacks, Tom had $120 left. Since he spent half on snacks, the $120 is the other half. So before buying snacks, he had $120 × 2 = $240. Before that, he spent $80 on a game, so at first he had $240 + $80 = $320.

questions.question: Complete the pattern: 15,200, 16,400, 17,600, 18,800, _____
questions.explanation: Find the difference between consecutive numbers: 16,400 − 15,200 = 1,200. 17,600 − 16,400 = 1,200. 18,800 − 17,600 = 1,200. The pattern increases by 1,200 each time. So 18,800 + 1,200 = 20,000.
